dialogues.speaker: BEGIN TITLES OVER
dialogues.text: It is early morning and already hot.  INSECTS drone, crac and scurry for shade.  PRAIRIE DOGS burrow to escape the We can see the heat shimmering off the surface of the Ear On a dusty highway, a pair of VULTURES dine on a dead coy One of them snags an intestine and tugs a few feet of it the carcass. In the distance, where a long, dusty road meets the horiz small shape appears -- a Sixty-four-and-a-half Mustang convertible, its top down.  Its candy-apple red burns lik brilliant fireball under the sun.  As the car drifts clos see steam escaping from under the hood.  Sammi Smith's "P Help Me Get Through The Night" plays on the car's radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the wheel, ignoring impending disaster, BOBBY COOPER, good-looking, fiddles with the RADIO dial, annoyed only t country stations. He's been driving since noon yesterday shows -- along with a heavily-bandaged left hand resting steering wheel. He finds something by Pearl Jam or Smashi Pumpkins and he cranks it. He pops a Percodan with his go as, in the shimmering distance ahead, he sees black shape the road and lays on the horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off the goddamn road!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the MUSTANG powers by, the VULTURES move off the shoul silently watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RADIO blares as BOBBY fights to stay awake. His atten caught by blue and red lights flashing in the oncoming la sits up as the POLICE CAR (SHERIFF POTTER inside) closes quickly. The SIREN starts faintly, then SCREAMS as the cr roars past at speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! There is a loud pop from the front of the Mustang and a t cloud of steam now pours from the hood. The temperature g now starts rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!...Not now!...Shit! A couple of SEMIS roar past in the opposite direction, buffetting the Mustang with their air waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car rolls into a fork in the road, limping with the d an animal that won't make another hundred yards. One sign on the larger road says "GLOBE" is 29 miles away other sign, on the lesser road, tells us "SUPERIOR" is on miles. A third sign confirms his destiny with "Gas, Food, Mile." BOBBY seems to have no choice. He aims the car down the l road towards "Superior, Arizona."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car rattles on its last legs, as BOBBY mutters incant noticing a old, ghostlike MINING COMPANY at the base of t mountains overlooking the TOWN. It's deserted now, no one visible, the gates shut, but in its vast, dark bulk, we s the ancient richness and power of this town. Bobby moves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the road from the MINING COMPANY, BOBBY'S CAR pulls small GAS STATION, made of weather-beaten wood, its windo since dusted over. The pumps themselves look to have been manufactured in the early fifties. Above the station is a so faded it's barely readable: HARLIN'S. Bobby gets out of the car and with great care, favoring h bandaged left hand which seems to give him a great deal o he opens the hood. A plume of steam hits him in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! Bobby looks around for someone, anyone.  After a few mome reaches into the car and blows the horn.  He waits, then it again.  From out of the station walks DARRELL - a slow-looking man in coveralls caked with grease and dirty looks the part of a yokel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Harlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Darrell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlin around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's up at the Look Out. Darrell points a scraggly finger at a plateau in the dist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will he be back soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doubt it.  He's dead.  The Look Out's a cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You own this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you call it Harlin's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause Harlin used to own it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Bobby is confused, but chooses to drop the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to take a look at my car?  I think the radiator hose is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.  Gonna be another hot one today. Sometimes I don't even want to get out of bed. Course don't want to get out for the cold one's neither.  Then of course the clouds come in... Darrell mops his brow with a greasy rag.  It doesn't so m wipe the sweat as it does streak his forehead with dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Harlin, I've got places to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darrell--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Darrell... Could you just take a look at my radiator hose.  It's busted. Darrell is clearly upset at being cut off.  He leans into car and looks at the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your radiator hose.  It's busted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's busted.  What did I just tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know so much why don't you just fix it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could do you think I'd be standing here wasting my time.  Can you fix it, or do I have to go somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere else?  Mister, somewhere else is fifty miles from here. Only other gas station down in town closed 3 years ago when the mine got shut...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm stuck.  You happy?  Now can you fix it, or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta run over to the yard and see if I can find a hose like this one, or close enough. Gonna take time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time. BOBBY (rewinds his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it now? DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-after-ten. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.  Twenty-after-ten and it must be ninety already. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninety-two.  Course half hour from now might be seventy-two. These clouds move around a lot. Bobby wipes the bandaged hand across his forehead. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand? Self-consciously Bobby quickly drops his hand to his side BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accident. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to be more careful. Hands is important.  Let me show you something. When I was a kid, now I don't know if you can still see it, but I gashed my fingers in a lawnmower. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very interested in this but is there someplace... DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diner up a piece.  Not much, but us simple folk like it. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back in a couple of hours.  And be careful with her, will you? Darrell slams down the hood. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a car. Bobby reaches into the car, pulls out a small ugly gym ba he slings onto his shoulder and moves to the trunk, pops BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just a car. It's a sixty-four and half Mustang convertible. That's the difference between you and me, and why you live here and I'm just passing through. The trunk lid rises in the air, partially blocking Bobby Darrell, acting as a partition between them. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now do you mind? I got to get some stuff out of the trunk. He throws the car key to Darrell who takes the hint, spit grotesquely into the dirt, scratches his nuts, and walks to the shack. Concealed by the trunk lid, Bobby pulls out a GUN (a .9mm Baretta), wrapped in a t-shirt, from the top of the bag. we see a flash of green money, lots of it. Sports pages a betting sheets are piled inside. With a look around, Bobb the gun and stashes it underneath the rubber mat in the t Briefly we notice a towing ROPE under the mat. There is a travel bag, from which he peels a fresh bottle of Percoda quickly taking two, as well as the sports page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DARRELL watches out of the darkened office through the fr window, as BOBBY slams the trunk and starts walking down road, with the bag on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY walks along a dusty patch of road into town past a saying "SUPERIOR - HOME OF THE GOLDEN DOOR RETIREMENT COMMUNITY." As he walks on, a pair of MOTORCYCLERS roar p their Harleys blanketing him in a cloud of DUST.  He shou after them, but his words are lost under the whine of the engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY hits town, such as it is:  The Freeway left here a years back. There are only a few little stores:  A genera store, a catalog outlet, a post office that doubles as a depot.  All of them built for the desert heat. The busies in town seems to be the truckstop/diner with a few 18 whe parked outside it. At the corner of one street sits an old BLIND MAN dressed raggedy clothes, perhaps an Indian. His SEEING-EYE DOG li to him. He's talking to TWO OLD MEN, veterans perhaps, In Spanish. They both have missing limbs and slide off with alcoholic looks as Bobby passes. The Blind Man yells out American Indian accent. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  You there! BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something, old man? BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me old man.  Ain't you got no respect, boy? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something? BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I want something.  I want you to run over to that machine and get me a pop. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that yourself? BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no, I can't do that myself.  I'm blind.  Can't you see that? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't-- BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you think I was doing out here with these glasses on?  Sunnin' myself? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I thought you were keeping the sun out of your eyes. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't got no eyes.  You want to see? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ no! BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost my eyes in Vyee-et-nam.  Lost them fighting the commies.  Fought the war and lost my eyes fightin' the commies just so you can come around here and make fun of me. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I was sorry. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sorry.  Just run over there and get me my pop before I die of thirst. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure.  You got change? BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change?  You want my change?  I fought the war and lost my eyes just so I could give you my change? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, old man.  Christ. Bobby walks across the street to a very old soda machine; bottles instead of cans.  The blind man shouts to Bobby. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a Dr. Peppa!  I don't want no Colas. Colas ain't nothing but flavored water. Bobby puts change in the machine and pulls out a bottle o Pepper.  He starts back to the blind man. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget to open it for me.  I can't be opening my own bottle. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ! Bobby goes back to the machine and opens the bottle, then back to the old man who pours a splash on the ground. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little for Mother Earth. I'm about fifty percent Indian, you know. To all our relations. He takes a hearty swig of the soda. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!  Just what I needed!  Want some? The blind man holds the bottle out to Bobby.  A string of runs from his lips to the bottle's neck. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pass. Bobby reaches down and pets the old man's dog. Flies buzz both the dog and the Blind Man. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better give your pooch a sip. He looks sick. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's 'cause he's dead. Bobby jumps back. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you wasn't pettin' him none, was you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you keeping a dead dog around for? BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's only just dead.  What was I supposed to do with him?  I can't take him away anywhere.  And nobody wants to take him for me.  Do you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no! BLIND MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See.  Ain't nothing I can do but keep him here beside me.  That's where he belongs anyways.  Me and Jesse, that's my dog, not anymore, but me and Jesse we been pals since the war when I lost my eyes.  He was just a pup then... a companion that's loyal, that'll keep coming back to you no matter how much you kick him...I miss him. (as Bobby moves away) I'll see ya later, unless I come across something worse. Bobby noticing a beautiful woman down the street, GRACE M compulsively turns and catches up to her.  She is dressed than the usual t-shirts and tank tops of this town -- per mail-ordered dress or a mother's hand-me-down.  With her hair and caramel skin, it is obvious she is Native Americ arms are full with an awkward package she can barely mana BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I give you a hand, beautiful? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to my car? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right on my way. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother told me never to accept offers from strangers. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Bobby.  Now I'm not a stranger anymore.  See how easy it is for us to get to know each other, beautiful? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to call me that? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know your real name. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I don't want you to. Grace stops walking. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, but if you didn't I think you would have kept on walking. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty full of yourself, aren't you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that about me, beautiful. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Grace. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I carry your package, Grace? Grace hesitates, then gives the package to Bobby.  He has trouble with it himself. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you can manage? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to carry your pack for you? Bobby blurts out emphatically. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He catches himself, and softens a bit. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've got it. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accident. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be more careful. They start walking towards Grace's car. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very nice of you to help me.  That package is kind of heavy, and it's so hot. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble at all, really. They get to a car and Bobby puts down the package. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't nothing. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this isn't my car.  It's down a ways. I should have parked closer.  I just didn't think it would be so heavy.  I could drive up. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.  I got it. Bobby takes up the package and they begin walking again. package seems to have gained weight. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just new drapes and curtain rods.  If I had known it was going to be so heavy I would have had them delivered up to the house. Bobby struggles with the package.  Sweat starts to sheet face. BOBBY (panting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a fact? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got tired of looking at the old drapes. My mother made them. Had them long as I can remember. You ever seen something and just knew you had to have it? BOBBY (straining)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course they cost a little more than I should really be spending.  But, damn it, I don't hardly ever do anything nice for myself.  I deserve nice things. BOBBY (can hardly talk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ... can't ... argue ... They arrive at a JEEP SAHARA. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it. Bobby practically drops the package.  He is covered with GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Bobby. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome, Grace. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not from around here, are you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you say that?  Just because I help a lady with her package? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have that dead look in your eyes like the only thing you live for is to get through the day. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just drove in this morning. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drove into Superior?  What for? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't have a choice.  My car overheated up the road. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky you didn't break down in the desert.  Day like today, you'd be dead in no time. When you leaving? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until my car's fixed.  I don't know how long that's going to take. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here I've made you all hot and sweaty. Grace steps to Bobby and places her hand against his ches rubs away some of the sweat. They look at each other a be POLICE CAR, seen earlier, pulls up beside them from behin idles. SHERIFF VIRGIL POTTER is a weathered, handsome, middle-aged man with suspicious eyes, black haired in con to Bobby's sandiness. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Grace. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Sheriff. Got my drapes. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's about time. Looks like you found yourself a helper too. Bobby wants to shrink behind the drapes. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he offered, and I just couldn't refuse. His car overheated. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Bobby turns to the Sheriff and forces a smile. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, officer. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son. (beat, to Grace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little excitement out at the reservation this morning. Wayne and Dale Elkhart were up drinking all night and then Wayne starts chasing Dale around the desert with his shotgun. BIA handled it. I went by for backup. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody hurt? SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no. That Wayne can't shoot when he's sober, much less drunk. He's lucky he didn't kill his own danged self. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyhow, you stay cool. Nice meeting you, son. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here, officer. The Sheriff drives on.  Pause.  They look at each other. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I could use some help getting this box into the house.  Not far. You could shower, get something cool to drink. Bobby considers the offer, but there's not much consideri do. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I could use something cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY rides along with GRACE in her JEEP. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you coming from? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All over.  Chicago, Houston, Detroit.  Just lately Dallas. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been around. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I've got wander in my blood. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you headed? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I have to make a stop in Vegas.  Business to finish.  Then maybe I'll head to Santa Barbara.  I might be able to pick up some action there. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what is it you do, Mister...? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooper. Bobby Cooper. Oh you know, whatever pays best. Little bartending, used to teach tennis, played a little competition ... (drops it). GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never played tennis. You just travel around Bobby-- no direction, no steady work.  You must like taking chances. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're going to gamble, might as well play for high stakes. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens when you lose? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pack up and go somewhere else. GRACE (wistfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere else.  I've never been anywhere else.  Just once.  Years ago.  Went to the State Fair. It was nice, but it wasn't nothing. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't stay in this place.  I wouldn't. I'd just pick up, do whatever I had to do, and get out. Grace looks to Bobby and smiles. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I feel the exact same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY, naked, steps into the shower and turns on the wate shoots from the shower head and cascades over his body. water falls over him we hear a Russian accented voice: VOICE(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my money. Bobby press his left hand against the white tile to stead himself.  His hand is curled in such a way we cannot see pinky or ring finger.  Bobby leans back in the shower.  J he does:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining hard.  Matching the backwards motion of the scene BOBBY is thrown violently against a brick wall, fac out. VOICE(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my money. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll get the money! You don't want to do this! VOICE (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take two for now. One a week, punk... Bobby is being pressed against the wall by two muscular G Another MAN stands partially hidden behind the goon's fra With one hand one goon flattens Bobby's hand against the with his other he clips two fingers off with a GARDEN SHE see Bobby's face in agonizing pain, then he slides scream the ground until he is framed between the legs of the men As Bobby clutches his left hand the rainwater runs in str down his ashen, blank face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see BOBBY's face reliving the experience as once again hear the voice. VOICE (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks, asshole. Get the money or you gonna lose your nose and ears. Bobby has slumped to the floor of the shower, looking to left hand, almost crying, unable to tolerate it.  As a st blood snakes down the white tile we see that the pinky an FINGERS have been cut off at the joints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY, his hand rebandaged, is putting on his clothes. BOBBY (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still lucky. As he does he looks at himself in the mirror.  He bends t up his shirt which is draped over the gym bag.  As he lif can see, perhaps more closely than at the garage, that th 3/4 filled with money.  He closes the bag and stands.  In MIRROR, hidden in the doorway, he sees GRACE watching him slows perceptibly, but does not try to hide himself.  Aft moment Grace walks into the room carrying a glass of lemo GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you might like a refill on your lemonade. Bobby takes the lemonade and drinks it down.  He rubs the against his forehead. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.  Cools you right off. (tentatively) I saw you watching me. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I didn't mean to. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say it bothered me. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like it; me watching you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.  I've got an ego same as any man. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, 'cause I liked what I saw. Bobby gives a smile as devilish as it is pleasant. Grace an ice cube from the glass between her lips. He notices a picture of GRACE and an OLDER MAN. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice place. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Grace sits on the edge of the bed. Bobby indicates the pi ironic. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that, your father? GRACE (without much thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepfather... BOBBY (coy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a boyfriend? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not really. Bobby senses she's lying but plays along. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must get kind of lonely for a woman living by herself in a big house. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it must. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do anyway? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little of this, a little of that.  Mostly I tell fortunes. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you learn to do that? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From my father.  He was the tribe's shaman. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medicine man? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are white words, not ours. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice house for a shaman's daughter.  You must be good. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here. Bobby goes to Grace and kneels before her.  She takes his in her hands and looks deep into his eyes.  Her voice goe thick, but soft, like a morning fog. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something in your past; something you want to keep hidden.  There's a pain. Something ... someone you can't forget. And there is something you want very badly. It seems very far away to you, but you are determined, and you will do what you must to get it. Bobby closes his hands on Grace's and takes them from his He is more than slightly spooked by the accuracy of Grace reading. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My face tell you all that? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It tells me what every face tells me. Everybody has a past, they have a pain, and they have something they want. (seductively) What is it you want? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same thing you do. They silently stare into each other's eyes. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  I want to hang drapes. Grace walks from the room.  For a moment Bobby stares aft He takes an ice cube from his glass and crunches it in hi teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE is standing on a step ladder trying to hang the dra BOBBY notices a photo of Grace with an older INDIAN WOMAN mother? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold me. Bobby stands behind her, gently places his hands on Grace waist. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tighter.  I won't break. You know girls are a lot tougher than men think. Bobby holds her tighter as she finished hanging the drape eyes are transfixed on her ass. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.  All done.  Lift me down. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift me down. Bobby lifts Grace down from the ladder.  He holds her, hi around her waist. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can let go of me now. I'm safe.(with a wicked smile) How do they look? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful? BOBBY (kidding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like they're made of polyester. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like them.  I was sick of looking at this room.  I think they add a little life. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like a little liveliness. With a sexy pout Grace loads the next question. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more drapes to hang.  Now what should we do? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an idea. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what would that be? Bobby steps close to Grace and takes her by the shoulders pulls her to him and presses his lips hard to hers.  Grac doesn't respond. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Grace.  No more games. GRACE (innocently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Games? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You flirt with me, then you run cold.  You lead me on, then slap me down.  I don't go for being jerked around. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  And what game did you want to play?  You carry my box for me, and I fall into bed with you? Bobby grabs up his pack. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can find my own way back to into town. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I like to find out about a man first. Maybe I like to know what he's made of. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just flesh and blood, baby.  That and a few memories of bad women; just like most guys.  But you already know that.  You read my mind, remember? Thanks for the lemonade. Bobby turns to leave. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never did answer my question. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still playing? GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not an answer.  What is it you want? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I want. GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I just want to hear you say it. For a beat Bobby stands and stares hard at Grace.  His pa slides from his shoulder and thuds on the floor.  With gr determination, like a beast closing for the kill, Bobby m for her.  Grace stands firm, ready for him; her head tilt Her breath comes deep and hard. Just as Bobby is about to reach her, just as he is about her, he is stopped dead by the booming voice of JAKE McKE JAKE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace! Bobby turns to face Jake:  An older man, still large and formidable for his age. GRACE (nonplussed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake.  I thought you... JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell is this!? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you? JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm her husband. BOBBY (shocked whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Husband ...? JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who the hell are you, and it better be good, or God help me I'll break you in half. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, chief. I... I was helping your wife. I met her in town.  She needed a hand with her drapes.  That's all. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't much look like you were hanging drapes. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to you that's all that happened.  I haven't so much as set foot in your bedroom. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot that means. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace, tell him. Grace says nothing.  She picks up a glass of lemonade and at it coolly. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, Grace!  Tell him. GRACE (coyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he says that's what happened, Jake, it must be true. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, and I suppose you didn't have anything to do with it Grace, he just wandered up here by hisself. I got a mind to put you over my knee and paddle your ass raw! BOBBY (to Grace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bitch! Is this what it's all about? You sucker me up here so you can watch the two of us beat the shit out of each other over you? You both... Forget it! (heads for the door) JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going! BOBBY (exiting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, you want to take my head off, mister. I won't even try to stop you. I deserve it for being an idiot. But if you're not, I think I'll be on my way... Ow! Jake punches him in the nose. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just walk in here and walk out, you sonufabitch! I'm gonna tear you a new asshole! BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You broke my nose! JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't broke. It probably isn't, but it bleeds. Bobby feels the blood a sees it on his shirt. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it! I'm... you're lucky I don't sue you. JAKE (opens the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get goin' Junior. Bobby glares back at Grace who gives him a maddening litt BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people are crazy! He storms out holding his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY, holding a handkerchief to his nose which has stopp bleeding, hauling his bag on his shoulder, walks back to along the side of the road. Already he is caked with a mi of sweat and dust, looking up at the relentless sun that down on him. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' shithole! A CADILLAC slows beside him, JAKE driving. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you want? JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a lift, son. Too hot to be walking... People die out here, y'know. Bobby continues walking. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you're not still upset about that love tap, are you? If I meant you real trouble, I'd have given it to you by now. Get in, lad. Come on. Get in. Bobby gets in. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you huffed off, Grace lied so bad, I got so pissed off, I pulled down her pants to paddle her ass raw and finger-fucked it instead. Sorry I lost my cool like that. It's a funny thing, women. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what happened to your hand? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accident. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be-- BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.  More careful. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we've never been introduced proper. Jake McKenna. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a solid name. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a solid man. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Cooper. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bobby Cooper." What brings you to Superior, Coop? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An overheated car. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Darrell taking good care of you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darrell's a moron. JAKE (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he sure is a character. You need any help with that car now?... Where you headed? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California... JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live there? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got work.  I know a man who's got a boat. Wants me to sail it for him. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a sailor man?  That'd be the life. Drive across the country, step on a boat and just sail away.  A man could pretty well disappear like that.  Just sail away until all he was was a memory.  I guess a little place like this would just be a dot on a map to you after awhile. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. (beat) Listen, McKenna about your wife:  If I had known she was married-- JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't have made a difference to you, now would it?  Not a wit.  Do you know why? Because you're a man without scruples. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second-- JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I can smell it on you. Jake wipes his hand across the back of Bobby's neck and h to his nose. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the sweat of a man who hasn't an honest bone in his body.  Don't be offended, lad.  A man who's got no ethics is a free man.  I envy that.  Beside, how can I blame you?  That Grace sure has a mind of her own, and a body to match, don't she?  Eh? Jake nudges Bobby who smiles a nervous smile. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does at that.  I knew when I married her she was a free spirit.  A woman with her looks and a man my age; what was I to expect?  But you see a woman like that in a town like this and you don't think, you do. So, I married her.  What are you to do, eh? Women. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't live with them, and you can't shoot 'em. Jake looks at Bobby, his lips curled into a sly smile. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You can't shoot 'em!" I like that. (laughs) I bet she led you on good, didn't she?  Taking you up to the house to hang drapes. Oh that's a good one. Bet she had you hard as a rock wiggling her ass in your face.  I bet you just wanted to pull down her pants and hog her out. Then me busting in like some wild bear. Ha! Bet you had a fire going under you. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you don't know. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mad like a dog in heat, I bet you were.  I can tell you got a temper on you. Bobby gives a little laugh. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you just wanted to snap her neck right then, didn't you?  Bet you just wanted to kill her. Bobby starts to laugh heartily.  Jake joins in, then stop abruptly. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I what? JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you kill her? Bobby starts to laugh. Bobby stops laughing. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm sick and tired of her little games.  Because you could do it and drift away on your boat and no one would ever see you again.  Because I've got a fifty-thousand dollar life insurance policy on her, and I would be more than happy to give the man who does her in a good chunk of it. For a moment Bobby sits in silence not sure of what to ma the offer. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done a few things but I'm not a murderer, Mr. McKenna. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know if you've never tried? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a joke, right?  You just want to rattle me.  Right? They reach town and Jake stops the car near a small GROCE STORE. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Nothing but a joke.  That's all. Bobby gets out of the car.  With a big smile Jake says: JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy your stay, lad. Jake speeds away.  Bobby looks after him. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is small and dark and empty save for a tiny, ol Mexican WOMAN who is behind the counter.  BOBBY enters. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any cold soda? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soda.  You got any soda? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hablar slowly, por favor.  My ingles no es bien. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soda.  You know. Bobby cups his hand and brings it to his mouth pantomimin WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Something to eat.  Si. She holds up a pack of Twinkies. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not eat.  Drink.  What the fuck is drink in Spanish ... uh, agua? The old woman's eyes widen.  She starts to scream, but qu clamps her hands over her mouth.  For a moment Bobby thin woman is screaming at what he has said.  Then, as if he f presence behind him, Bobby turns slowly to face the TWO tough-looking, unshaven, tattoo-covered BIKERS.  One hold gun. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, lady.  Keep it in you and nobody gets hurt.  That goes for you too, stud.  Gimmie the money.  Now! WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh? SECOND BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dinero, Senora.  Hand it over. Bobby shifts his weight trying to hide his pack behind hi The woman goes to an old-fashioned cash register and ring open.  She hands the money to the biker. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?  Lady, I got kids to put through school. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Es all I have. The biker turns to Bobby. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, pal.  Whatcha got? Give it, now. Bobby pulls a thick wad of cash ($1,000 plus) from his pa pocket, tosses it on the counter. BIKER (thumbing through it, impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice...Just who are you beautiful? What else you got for papa? Bobby makes a show of pulling out his wallet, flings it t BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better...you're getting tasty. Now toss the bag, sweetie. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just books. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a reader. Toss it. BOBBY (an entreaty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's personal things...family things. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How touching...I like family values. Give it to me. Bobby takes an unsteady breath. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? SECOND BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, forget it. Come on. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senor, give him the bag. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. He doesn't want to give me the bag... SECOND BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fucking with you man. Shoot him. BIKER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he doesn't have to give me the bag. The biker grabs Bobby's bag. Bobby flinches in anticipati shot but refuses to let go of the bag.  The biker swings hard, clipping Bobby across the forehead.  Bobby falls ag the counter and to the floor.  The woman starts to scream biker grabs up the pack, then, looking back at the woman, ring on her finger.  He grabs her hand and pulls at the r The woman screams wildly. SECOND BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, man. BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little extra never hurt, Benji, would you just relax. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  No! My wedding ring. He pulls the ring from the woman's finger and pushes her With Bobby's bag slung over his shoulder he turns to leav BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we go. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to El Diablo! From beneath the counter the woman pulls a shotgun. The w fires A SHOT that rips through the bag and into the back biker.  He falls to the ground, very dead, amid a shower blood and shredded money. SECOND BIKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger! You bitch! The Second Biker now sees the money floating all over the out of the torn bag. His eyes go big with greed as he FIR the old woman, who ducks behind the counter. The Biker grabs for the bag and what's left of the money, expecting the feisty old lady to pop up and unload her SE BLAST into him and the bag. Whatever was left of the money on the first round is now shreds along with the bag and the Biker who is very dead. Bobby is staggered, crawls towards the shreds. WOMAN (cursing in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hijos de puta. Bayan a comer su propia mierda en el infierno. (TRANSLATION: Sons of bitches. Go eat your own shit in hell). She comes around the counter to his side as he grabs his and the $1000 cash roll from the dead biker's pants. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call the sheriff. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No police. Bobby gives her a hundred dollars. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred dollars? No police? Bobby gives her some more cash. She looks at him. Finally gives her the entire wad. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No police until I leave. Bobby stumbles from the store as the screen burns a brigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY, dazed and holding his head, sits on the ground nex SPIGOT that is dripping water.  He cups his hands under t water and splashes it against his face, lightly wiping th above his eye. The SHERIFF'S CAR goes wailing by on the m drag. Recoiling from being spotted, Bobby tries to take a drink. A SCORPION crawls out of the faucet. He jumps back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DARRELL is leaning under the hood of a car working on its as BOBBY walks up. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, your ... what the hell happened to you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look like nothing. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just banged my head.  It was an accident. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another accident?  You got to be more careful. Bobby rolls his eyes. Then notices the front fenders have removed. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened to my car? DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottom hose was shot too.  Rotted clear through. Had to put a new one in. Runs like a dream now. BOBBY (suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much? DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... you got your parts, you got your labour ... let's call it a hundred-fifty bucks. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much!? DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred-fifty. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To replace a goddamn radiator hose!? DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A goddamn radiator hose in a sixty-four-and-a-half Mustang.  You know how long it took me to find that hose? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About an hour and a half, because that's all the longer I've been gone. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's been about three hours. You're the one thinks that car's so damn fancy.  What you expect but fancy damn prices? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a Ford, not a Ferrari.  You going to tell me no one else in this shit hole drives a Ford? DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That's not just a Ford, that's a sixty-four-and-a-half Mustang." BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with the radiator hose? DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but "it's the reason I'm living here and you're just passing through."  Now you owe me a hundred-fifty dollars. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might as well be fifteen-hundred dollars, because I don't have the money. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you ain't gonna have the car. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, man.  I got rolled half an hour ago for everything I had. Bobby digs through his bloodied wallet, trying to hide it Darrell. He fishes out a five dollar bill. Then digs out bloody one dollar bill from his pocket. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got five...six dollars. Darrell snatches the five from him and adds it to a thick greasy bills he carries in his overalls. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're only a hundred-forty-five in the hole.  You can keep that dollar. Now why don't you just take your American Express Gold Card, and call that guy with the big schnooz on TV and have him send you the money lickity split. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a goddamn credit card. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's too bad.  I sure hope you know how to wash dishes or shovel shit 'cause you're gonna have to work this one off. Bobby proffers his Movado watch. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I got a Movado.  It's worth at least seven, eight hundred. You could sell it for that. DARRELL (studying it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell to? Shit, can't see no numbers. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need numbers.  That's why it's expensive.  Look at the gold. Darrell doubts that, shake his head. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...got no day, got no date.  Probably ain't worth a duck's fart (proffers his own watch). This one here cost me $3.75 and it's got every doodad you can imagine. No sir I'll stick with this (walks away). BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch! I'll have my lawyers shut you down. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't got no credit card but you got a lawyer. Sweet talk me all you want.  Didn't you read the sign? It says... BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sign? Fuck the sign. I want my car. DARRELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my hundred and forty-five dollars. Bobby stands his ground for a moment as if deciding wheth not to fight for the car, then wheels and walks away. Darrell looks at him, smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a little worn diner-type stop one would find on mos open road:  Counter with stools, laminated menus, a Wurli the corner belching out country TUNES.  Business is slow it's the only restaurant in town. There is a SHORT ORDER the kitchen, and FLO, a hard-looking waitress is behind t counter.  A couple of regular drivers, ED and BOYD, are s on the stools, Boyd is flipping a coin. ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-hundred-thirteen degrees.  That was back in July of forty-seven. That afternoon it dropped down to forty three! True story. BOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One time last year I remember it went from 98 to 23 same day. Wind, black clouds come out like... BOBBY comes out of the men's room and sits at the end of counter.  He has cleaned himself up a bit but still looks mess. He buries his face in the menu. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a beer? FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck's. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Beck's. A-1, Coors... BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heineken? FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we ain't got no Heineken.  We got Miller. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genuine Draft? FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Just plain ol' Miller. Now you can fuckin' take it or you can fuckin' leave it. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fuckin' take it. To go. SHORT ORDER COOK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flo, cheeseburger bleedin'. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back with that beer. Flo moves off. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and a waitress named Flo.  Christ. As Bobby stares at the money on the counter in front of h hears, from somewhere outside the diner, the sound of a P RADIO crackling. He now feels something against his foot. looks down and sees a CAT rubbing against his leg.  He gi a good kick sending it sliding across the floor with a sc BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking cat. In the background, two teenagers sit at a booth.  TOBY lo part of a local, wearing jeans and a white T-shirt.  His cropped close and he looks to be a senior in high school. girl, JENNY, is nondescript, neither ugly nor beautiful. the kind of girl most guys would pass without a second lo Toby gets up from his booth and goes to the bathroom.  Af is gone Jenny walks to Bobby. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mister.  You gotta quarter for the juke? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna play a song on the juke.  You got a quarter? Bobby looks at Jenny, then picks a quarter from his winni flips it to her. He can't resist putting a little charm i JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cut it shaving; I know, I gotta be more careful. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any requests? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That country shit all sounds the same to me. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about I pick one out for you? Bobby half smiles.  Jenny plays a song.  Patsy Cline's "Y Cheatin' Heart."  Jenny takes up a stool next to Bobby's. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like Patsy Cline?  I just love her. How come, I wonder, she don't put out no more new records. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause she's dead. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, that's sad.  Don't that make you sad? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had time to get over it. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not from around here, are you? Where you from? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't from Oz.  Oz is in that movie. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too quick for me. Toby walks back into the room.  He looks at Jenny.  He lo Bobby.  He looks at Jenny talking to Bobby.  He loses it. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No....No....No I'm seeing but I'm not believin'...Stop the wedding.  This can't be. Hey!  What are you doing with my girl? Bobby says nothing, ignoring Toby. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I axed you a question. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Toby, we weren't doing nothing.  We was just talking. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shut your mouth, girl, and get back over to our table. (to Bobby) Now, I'm not going to axe you again, Mister.  What were you doing with my girl? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't doing anything. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the way it looked to me.  Looked to me like you was trying to make time with her. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make time?  Is everybody in this town on drugs? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest, Toby.  I just axed him for a quarter for the jukebox. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of this, Jenny.  We got man's business to take care of. I ain't never taken no drugs, mister, and ... BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe you should've. Look, pal, I wasn't making a play for your girl. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to believe that? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what you believe as long as you leave me alone. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, I'm calling you out. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  You want to fight?  Over her? Bobby looks Jenny over. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, you go finish your soda and leave the man alone. TOBY (to Bobby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who I am?  Toby N. Tucker. Everyone round here call me TNT. You know why? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see...they're not very imaginative? TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'm just like dynamite.  And when I go off, somebody gets hurt. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  I was making time with your girl. Now I'm scared to death and I learned my lesson. Now can you go away? TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not before I settle with you, chickenshit! BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, I don't believe this! TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand up. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't hitting on your girl! TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand up, Mister, or I'll beat you where you sit. Bobby sits for a beat. he doesn't need a fight with Toby with his damaged hand nor does he need to be noticed eith sits there. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, you stop it now! Can't you see he's got a hurt hand? TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you never mind, Flo.  This is gonna be over real quick. Reluctantly Bobby rises, facing off against Toby, each cl their fist and waiting for the other to make the first mo The tension builds.  We see it on the faces of Jenny, Flo the regulars.  Just then the record on the juke ends and needle scratches off.  There is the crackle of a police r the door to the diner opens and SHERIFF VIRGIL POTTER wal The tension eases. Toby, mindful of the sheriff, steps cl Bobby and whispers menacingly into his ear. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky, Mister.  Don't think it's over.  I called you out and I'm gonna see this through.  You hear me? (to Jenny) Come on, girl.  I got half a mind to make you walk home. Toby takes Jenny by the arm and pulls her out of the dine FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord, that little baby of yours Virgil, has gotten cuter'n a bunny's nose. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that all about? FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how that Toby is.  Thinks every man he sees is after his Jenny. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like Jenny is after every man she sees. FLO (to Bobby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pay Toby no mind.  He just likes to show off for his girl.  Give him a couple of hours, he'll cool off.  Still want that beer? BOBBY (tense, seeing the Sheriff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it to go. Bobby holds his hand to his face to cover the cut on his forehead. ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it with you, Sheriff? SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already started out bad.  Couple of bikers from out of town tried to knock over Jamilla's grocery store this morning. It was a real shootout. BOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old witch killed 'em both. ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit! FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor thing.  Is she all right? SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, when the sons of bitches tried to steal her wedding ring. That's when she started shooting.  Can't blame her.  The ring was all Carlos left her when he died. Store's a mess. BOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the desert.  That's what it is.  The desert makes everybody crazy.  Ain't that right, Sheriff?  People go crazy out here. ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Boyd.  I've got to make tracks. That yogurt's got to make Santa Fe before it spoils. BOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Pepper don't have that problem. Ed and Boyd toss a few bills on the counter and exit.  Fl stands near the cash register with Bobby's beer. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't open off-sale for you, sugar. Bobby pays for the beer ($1.75).  Flo opens the register. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get your change. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flo, I'm just gonna help myself to a refill on the coffee. The Sheriff reaches around the counter for the pot. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be careful now, Virgil. Just as the words leave Flo's mouth the Sheriff spills th It shatters against the floor spilling hot coffee everywh Flo runs over to him. SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgil!  Now look at what you done!  Are you all right? SHERIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I burned my gun hand! As Flo bends to wipe the counter, Virgil touches her inti SHERIFF (Cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout we put something soft on it later? (a look) FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I could put some butter on it, hon'. (Her normal abrasive voice) It'd serve you right, you asshole.  Put it under some cold water. Joe, run get a mop and clean this fuckin' mess up. While everyone is distracted Bobby notices that the regis drawer has been left open.  He looks around to make sure not being watched.  Slowly he eases his hand towards the It gets closer and closer.  As he is about to grab the mo there, the cat - the same one he kicked away earlier - hi and claws at his hand.  Bobby jumps back startled. FLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shasta!  Now why'd you go and scare the nice man like that?  Sorry about that, mister.  Let's see, you want $3.25. (gives it to him) You try to have a nice day now, would you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'll try. With the Sheriff occupied, and the Mexican Jose mopping t floor, Bobby exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY begs on the phone. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cici?  Cici, it's Bobby...Bobby Cooper...Yeah, look, I know it's been a while, but I'm kind of in a jam...yeah...One-hundred-fifty dollars...That's a lie. I called you on your birthday..Two years ago...I can't help it if you didn't get the message. Cici, honey, I don't want to argue. I need you to wire me the money...Because they're fucking going to KILL ME!  I didn't steal your CD's...Yeah, well where's my Mr. Coffee. Cici...Cici... Bobby slams the phone. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch. Cunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY is on another call, circling a local sports page be line. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73-11, this is Pluto. What's the line on Dallas? GAMBLER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pluto. Fucking deadbeat. We head about you. You owe "the commie" 13 dimes, why you tryin' to get in my office? Lose this fuckin' number. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike...Mike...you asshole. GAMBLER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike who? (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, frustrated, clicks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the kind of cheesy, temporary office one would expe find in a Las Vegas apartment building overlooking the DO STRIP.  MR. ARKADY, dressed in a silk suit with conspicuo jewelry, sits behind his desk eating lunch and cleaning h nails.  SERGEI, his goon in a shiny polyester shirt, hove his boss helping feed and manicure him.  These are the TW from Bobby's earlier FLASHBACK.  They are dangerous in an endearing way.  Sergei answers the phone. In the backgrou very voluptuous female, obviously from the Middle East. S SERGEI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da? MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergei, what are you, a Neanderthal? How many times do I have to tell you?  You answer a phone "hello," not "da." SERGEI (nods yes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Arkady.(into phone)"Hello?" OPERATOR(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a collect call from Bobby Cooper. Will you accept the charges? SERGEI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arkady, deadbeat Cooper's calling. Mr. Arkady doesn't acknowledge him. SERGEI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's calling collect. At this Mr. Arkady's head springs up.  He snatches the ph from Sergei. MR. ARKADY (overly sweet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, what a surprise.  I expected to be seeing you, not talking to you over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY on the phone. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Mr. Arkadin. I know. I was on my way to you, it's just ... what a day I've had. I know I'm coming up with a highly improbable story, and I know you're not going to believe this, but this ...is... what happened. I had the money, I swear I had it. I was on my way to Vegas when my car breaks down in the middle of nowhere. Mr. Arkady cleans his nails completely disinterested in w Bobby is saying. MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a shame, Bobby.  A real shame. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's not the half of it, Mr. Arkadin... MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Arkady" BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Mr. Arkady. And that's not the half of it. I got your money, and I go into this little grocery store in this hicktown to get something to eat and then... well, it gets robbed! MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And let me guess.  This robber -- he gets your money. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Two of them. Two robbers. And they both get nailed... get shot by the old lady. MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old lady? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a shotgun!  She kills both of 'em, and... and the money in my bag gets all shredded to bloody pieces. Not one bill is left alive.  I mean, what are the odds? MR. ARKADY (beat, dry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty long, Bobby. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arkady, honest, I ad to beat it outta there before the cops showed. So now I don't have a cent to my name. I can't even get my car out of the garage.  I tell you, Mister... (pause) if it weren't for bad luck I wouldn't have nay fuckin' luck at all, you know? (beat, waits)  So, I was wondering if you could wire me a hundred fifty-dollars so I could get my car out of this garage, see?  The bus depot here has a Western Union thing.  And of course I'll pay it back with the rest of the money. MR. ARKADY(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which you don't have. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But which I can get. No problem. Look, I can sell my car in Vegas. Blue book it's worth 16 at least. I just need the 150, uh... Sergei looks like he's ready to pound heads. MR. ARKADY (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? BOBBY (hopeful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...a little shithole in Arizona called Superior. About 200 miles east of Phoenix. MR. ARKADY (pausing, V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superior, hunh? Bobby suddenly feeling suspicious. BOBBY(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you could send it care of... MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now, let me get this straight. Two years you give me problems with your fuckin' payoffs. Now you owe me thirteen-thousand dollars, you call me - collect - then ask me to wire you one-hundred-fifty dollars just so you can get your car fixed. BOBBY(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred-forty-five would probably cover it. MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred and ... Now you listen to me you deadbeat little punk:  I don't care if you got hit by a truck and run over by a steamroller.  You owe me thirteen-thousand dollars and I want it.  I don't care how you get it, or where from, but I want it on my desk tomorrow, or I'll show you what real bad luck is. Sergei snaps a pencil he's holding in his hand, which goe flying by Arkady's head, forcing him to duck. MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand me you little fuck? BOBBY (snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck you too! MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say to me! BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit I'm sorry!...you can't believe the strain I'm under. I'm just under a lot of strain here. There is a sharp silence at the other end. Bobby waits. MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, you owed me that 'bread' 4 weeks ago. Now you tell me you want another week. That's 5 weeks, Bobby. That's also 5 fingers, cause you and I know it's a finger a week Bobby. So you got balls. Good--now you come here tomorrow and you talk to me real nice and maybe I don't take the other 3 fingers you owe me, you see? Tomorrow -- and Bobby, don't make me come look for you, okay...have nice day. He hands the phone back to Sergei. SERGEI (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that? -- have nice day (hangs up). MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nerva that piece of shit! And look at you, you Neanderthal -- don't you fuckin' break pencils, you goombah! SOFIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finger? What are you, a faggot? In my country a man don't pay we cut off his head. Arkady motions Sergei to come close. MR. ARKADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your ass down to this Superior, Arizona. Bring me this Bobby Cooper. I don't think he got the lesson. This is your last chance, Sergei. SERGEI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY, desperate, stares at the bandage of his wounded ha throbs, holding the hand to his ear. We hear an OPERATOR'S VOICE: OPERATOR(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? OPERATOR(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished with your call? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. OPERATOR(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please deposit an additional seventy-five cents. Bobby slams the phone against the hook. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn rat's ass fuck! Shit! Damn! Damn! Damn! He marches from the phone booth, past an old HARDWARE STO phone falls from the hook and we hear a recorded voice: VOICE(V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for using AT&T. In the store window, Bobby notices a set of garden shears sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY walks a bit going nowhere in particular.  Looking a watch thinking of Mr. Arkady, he shields himself with one from the sun.  At the side of an old building, in the bit shade it throws, he twists at the beer cap which sticks a won't turn.  Bobby tries again twisting harder -- too har the cap jerkily twists off, cutting into his hand as it r Bobby yells in pain.  At the same time the beer comes foa from the bottle and spills onto his sleeve. The bottle sl from his wet fingers and crashes on the ground, emptying. clutches his bleeding hand, pissed. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck! Fuck! Fuck! I hate this fuckin' town! I hate it! Do you hear me? (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me outta here, please.  I gotta get out of this place. As if in answer, a JEEP drives by on the main street. GRA looks pretty hot up there in the driver's seat, her eyes, sunglasses, flicking over him but not acknowledging him a keeps going. Bobby's eyes throw back his own hostility at her, but unfortunately she misses it, as he now notices -- across street -- a well-kept building with the most modern decor signage, reading "McKenna's Realty Co." He thinks about it, in a quandary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a rented convertible, we now see SERGEI racing across desert. His jacket off, a man with a mission. He glances watch, eager to get to this "fucking hole in the wall" wh somewhere on this incomprehensible American map he holds hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY squats, looking at a real estate model of a desert development. JAKE smiles. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, lad? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping we could talk. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk?  About what? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About things.  About your wife. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Grace?  What about her? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what you said this morning. Jake shakes his head as if he doesn't understand. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you had an insurance policy out on your wife.  Fifty-thousand dollars. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you'd cut that up with the man who did her in. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't play simple with me, Jake. You're a betting man. You want me to spell it out for you? I'll kill Grace if you cut me in on the money. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy I think this heat's getting to you the way you're rambling on. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not rambling. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking like a madman. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, I guess that qualifies me for citizenship in this town. You're the one brought it up. This morning. In your car. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was just loose talk. Husband gettin' pissed off.  I don't want anybody dead. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  You wanted me to kill her. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man doesn't always mean the things he says. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You meant it. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're a slimy bastard who would have his wife killed just to get his hands on some money. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does that make you? BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slimy bastard who's going to do it for you... (pause) You're a jealous man Jake. If you can't have Grace to yourself...well, you're not the sharing kind. For a moment Jake stares quietly at Bobby. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I have what you call a love-hate relationship with Grace. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love her, but you hate her? JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I hate loving her. I hate the kind of person she is. I hate having to tolerate the little "games" she plays. Like fucking half of the town behind my back and laughing at me. The bitch. She loved to play. She wants me to hit her and when I hit her she likes it. She tortures me. But she's family. She's my little girl. My baby. I couldn't stand to watch her eyes roll back in her head as she sucks her last breath, or to see her pretty pink brains spill from her skull. No. Not me. But you? You got the killing in you, boy...How much you want? A pause. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it twenty. JAKE (stressed, paces)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-thousand?  I don't have that kind of money.  I won't get the insurance until months after she's dead.  I don't imagine you'll want to be stickin' around after poor Grace's demise.  Twenty-thousand; that's more money than I could ever get my hands on. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much could you get? JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe ... ten-thousand.  And that's a maybe. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need thirteen. JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a bit much. BOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
